case_vignette: A 28-year-old man presents to the office complaining of a sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and difficulty opening his mouth for the past 5 days. He states that he had symptoms like this before and "was given some antibiotics that made him feel better". He is up to date on his immunizations. On examination, his temperature is 39.5°C (103.2°F) and he has bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. An oropharyngeal exam is difficult, because the patient finds it painful to fully open his mouth. However, you are able to view an erythematous pharynx as well as a large, unilateral lesion superior to the left tonsil. A rapid antigen detection test is negative.
question: Which  is a serious complication of the most likely diagnosis?
